courseInfo.prerequisite: Basic understanding of computer hardware and software.

rationale: The "System Administration & Practice" course is designed to equip diploma-level students in their third semester with essential skills for managing and maintaining computer systems effectively, preparing them for entry-level IT roles. By focusing on operating system installation, user management, disk and resource administration, security implementation, backup strategies, and automation through scripting, the course addresses the core responsibilities of a system administrator. This curriculum builds on prior foundational IT knowledge, ensuring students develop the technical proficiency and skills needed to support system software & hardware.

courseOutcomes.description: Install OS and understand role of system administrator
Manage users and groups, including creation, modification, deletion, permissions, and password policies
Monitor and control system processes, managing services, and analyzing performance
Write and execute basic shell scripts using variables, control structures, and cron scheduling to automate administrative tasks
Perform disk management, file system maintenance, and backup/recovery techniques using various commands

content: Overview of Linux Systems: Introduction to Operating system, History and distributions of Linux, Differences Between Windows and Linux, Role of a system administrator
Linux File System Basics: File system hierarchy (FHS), Navigating directories and file permissions
Basic Commands and Tools: Essential shell commands (ls, cd, pwd, cat, etc.), Using man pages and help systems
Managing Users: Creating, modifying, and deleting users, Password management and policies, Commands: useradd, usermod, userdel, passwd, chage, id
Managing Groups: Group creation and membership, Assigning privileges to groups, Commands: groupadd, groupmod, groupdel, gpasswd, groups, usermod -aG
File Permissions and Ownership: Understanding chmod, chown, and chgrp, Special permissions, Commands: chmod, chown, chgrp, ls -l, find
Process Management: Viewing and controlling processes, Background and foreground processes, Commands: ps, top, kill, bg, fg, jobs
System Services: Introduction to systemd, Starting, stopping, and enabling services, Commands: systemctl, service, chkconfig (legacy)
Monitoring System Performance: Tools like top, htop, and free, Log file analysis, Commands: top, htop, free, vmstat, cat, tail, less, Log files: /var/log/syslog, /var/log/messages
Introduction to Shell Scripting: What is a shell script?, Bash basics, Writing and executing a simple script
Variables and Control Structures: Defining variables and user input, If-else statements and loops (for, while)
Automating Administrative Tasks: Scripting file backups and user management, Scheduling scripts with cron
Disk Management: Partitioning and formatting disks, Commands: fdisk, mkfs, Mounting and unmounting file systems (mount, umount)
File System Maintenance: Checking and repairing file systems, Managing disk quotas, Commands: fsck, quota, quotacheck, edquota, setquota
Backup and Recovery: Using tar and cp for backups, Restoring files from backups

practicalOutcomes.outcome: Install Linux operating system and compare with Windows OS
Execute general-purpose commands on Linux (date, time, cal, clear, banner, tty, script, man) and equivalent Windows commands (e.g., date, time, cls, whoami, systeminfo)
Study the responsibilities of a system administrator conceptually
Navigate and explain the purpose of key FHS directories
Practice directory navigation and basic permission management
Execute and understand basic shell commands for file manipulation
Access and interpret command documentation
Create and customize user accounts with specific attributes in Linux, configure and verify password aging and security policies, remove a user account and associated data safely
Create a group and manage user membership within it, alter group properties and remove groups as needed
Modify file permissions and ownership for access control in Linux. Configure Windows file permissions using GUI and icacls command
Implement SUID, SGID, and sticky bit for advanced access scenarios
Monitor and terminate processes using system tools in Linux and Windows
Control process execution states (background/foreground)
Start, stop, and enable system services in Linux and Windows OS
Assess system performance using resource monitoring tools
Interpret system logs for troubleshooting and monitoring
Create and run a basic shell script to automate a task
Use variables and user input in a script for dynamic behavior
Apply conditional statements and loops for script logic
Automate a file backup process using a shell script
Schedule a script to run automatically using cron
Partition and format a disk for use in a Linux system
Mount and unmount a file system to manage storage access
Verify and repair file system integrity using diagnostic tools
Configure disk quotas to limit user storage usage
Perform a file backup using archiving and copying tools
Restore files from a backup to recover data

studentActivities: Compare Linux vs. Windows OS Features - Create a comparison table highlighting key differences
Identify Linux Distributions - Research and present the major Linux distributions and their use cases
System Installation Walkthrough - Document the steps for installing a Linux OS
Command Cheat Sheet Creation - Compile a reference sheet for common Linux commands and their Windows equivalents
File System Hierarchy Exploration - Prepare a visual representation of the Linux FHS structure
User and Group Management Case Study - Simulate a real-world scenario where user access control is essential
Shell Command Challenge - Conduct a timed challenge where students execute specific commands
Real-World System Admin Interview - Invite a system administrator for a Q&A session
Permission Troubleshooting Activity - Identify and fix incorrect file permissions in a given scenario
Process Management Scenario - Analyze and optimize running processes on a Linux system
Service Management Simulation - Configure and troubleshoot system services in different states
System Performance Analysis Task - Record system performance metrics and discuss optimization strategies
Log File Investigation Exercise - Analyze system logs to identify common issues
Shell Scripting Mini-Project - Automate a daily task using a shell script
Backup and Recovery Drill - Simulate a system failure and restore files from a backup
Disk Partitioning Hands-on - Create, format, and mount a new partition on a Linux system
Cron Job Scheduling Experiment - Automate a task using cron and document the process
Security Enhancement Task - Implement security measures like file permissions and access control
Network Configuration Task - Set up a basic Linux network and test connectivity
Final System Administration Challenge - Apply all learned skills to troubleshoot a misconfigured Linux system
